guide.introduction:
First of all: If you're not familiar with DeadDrops, visit deaddrops.com!

You surely know these new type of USB sticks which are very thin because they don't have the classic-iron USB connector. I had a bunch of them at home and wanted to use them as DeadDrops, but in my opinion the plastic connector is not solid enough for a DeadDrop's life of rain, physical stress, and vandalism. I solved this problem by soldering an end of an USB cable to them. I think that's really easy, so get your slim USB stick and an old cable or connector and get started!

First of all: If you're not familiar with DeadDrops, visit deaddrops.com!

You surely know these new type of USB sticks which are very thin because they don't have the classic-iron USB connector. I had a bunch of them at home and wanted to use them as DeadDrops, but in my opinion the plastic connector is not solid enough for a DeadDrop's life of rain, physical stress, and vandalism. I solved this problem by soldering an end of an USB cable to them. I think that's really easy, so get your slim USB stick and an old cable or connector and get started!

Relevant parts
  • Slim USB Stick
Tools
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire cutter/stripper

lines.text: If your stick has got any kind of  a non-solid plastic casing, remove it.
lines.text_raw: If your stick has got any kind of  a non-solid plastic casing, remove it.

lines.text: Removing the plastics can be done using a knife, a screwdriver or a Dremel-kind-of-tool.
lines.text_raw: Removing the plastics can be done using a knife, a screwdriver or a Dremel-kind-of-tool.

lines.text: You should end up having the circuit board (as in my case) or the elemental plastic part with the connectors.
lines.text_raw: You should end up having the circuit board (as in my case) or the elemental plastic part with the connectors.

lines.text: Be sure that you are opening only the outer plastic casing and not the inner one!
lines.text_raw: ''Be sure that you are opening only the outer plastic casing and '''not''' the inner one!''

lines.text: To get ready for soldering, you have to prepare your USB cable / USB male connector first.
lines.text_raw: To get ready for soldering, you have to prepare your USB cable / USB male connector first.

lines.text: If you are using a cable end:
lines.text_raw: '''If you are using a cable end:'''

lines.text: Gently remove about 1-2 cm of the outer plastic insulation of the cable.
lines.text_raw: Gently remove about 1-2 cm of the outer plastic insulation of the cable.

lines.text: Remove the tinfoil shielding by peeling it back and cutting it off. (Sometimes the shielding consists of many small wires. Don't worry, cut 'em off too!)
lines.text_raw: Remove the tinfoil shielding by peeling it back and cutting it off. (Sometimes the shielding consists of many small wires. Don't worry, cut 'em off too!)

lines.text: Now strip the four colored wires.
lines.text_raw: Now strip the four colored wires.

lines.text: If you are using a male connector:
lines.text_raw: '''If you are using a male connector:'''

lines.text: Remove any plastics that are covering the inner parts of your connector using a knife.
lines.text_raw: Remove any plastics that are covering the inner parts of your connector using a knife.

lines.text: Now it is time to solder the USB stick and the connector or wire together.
lines.text_raw: Now it is time to solder the USB stick and the connector or wire together.

lines.text: Be sure to solder the connections right and stick to the image if in doubt. (Oh, and sometimes the green wire is blue.)
lines.text_raw: Be sure to solder the connections right and stick to the image if in doubt. (Oh, and sometimes the green wire is blue.)

lines.text: If you like you can use heat-shrink tubing and/or hot glue to secure the solder connections.
lines.text_raw: If you like you can use heat-shrink tubing and/or hot glue to secure the solder connections.

lines.text: After that you just have to wrap the finished USB stick with some tape to make it waterproof and you're done!
